subject: RE: [junit] Gathering and displaying supplemental information about 	test failures.

You might consider extending/changing/refactoring JUnit itself using github=
.

There you can fork JUnit itself and submit your idea for inclusion for e=
veryone.  It is a very easy system.  Yet, Kent and David do an excellent jo=
b keeping the code consistent.  (Enhancements are considered, but there is =
a high bar for inclusion into the code base.)

With all that said, I think =
David Saff response covers your initial question.

Big Mike

From: junit@ya=
hoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Sunburned Surveyo=
r
Sent: Friday, November 20, 2009 1:22 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject=
: Re: [junit] Gathering and displaying supplemental information about test =
failures.



Mike,

I've never seen it. I am interested, but ultimately we =
are looking for a
solution that will work outside of Eclipse. We are workin=
g on an open source
library, and we can't know what IDE/build environment o=
ther contributors
will be using.

Maybe if I get something worked up they w=
ould consider making it a
supplemental part of JUnit. In the worst case, I'=
ll make a distro of my code
available on SourceForge.

Landon

20, 2009 at 11:20 AM, Forsberg, Mike <
mike.forsberg@...<ma=
ilto:mike.forsberg%40globalfoundries.com>> wrote:

>
>
> Have you looked at=
 how eclipse handles AssertEquals of two Strings.
>
> Not sure if this is a=
 JUnit core functionality or not. But eclipse
> highlights how the two stri=
ngs differ.
>

ll send screen

> Big Mike

 On Behalf Of Sunburned
> Surveyor
> Sent: Friday, November 20, 2009 12:06 =
PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com<mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> <junit%40yah=
oogroups.com>
> Cc: Martin Davis; Martin Davis
> Subject: [junit] Gathering=
 and displaying supplemental information about
> test failures.
>
>
> I hav=
e a question about the options for gathering and displaying
> supplemental =
information about test failures. Please allow me to
> illustrate my questio=
n with a simple example.
>
> I've got a class called Coordinate that repres=
ents a point in a 3D
> coordinate system. I've overloaded the toString meth=
od of this class
> to write out the X, Y, and Z values of the coordinate in=
 a simple
> String. Now I want to test my toString method using JUnit.
>
> =
If the Coordinate.toString test method fails (because the string was
> not =
constructed in the correct format) I would like to provide the
> programmer=
 running the test with a copy of the incorrect string, since
> it provides =
valuable clues about what is broken with the method under
> test. I typical=
ly do this by placing System.err.println statements in
> my test method. Ho=
wever, I realize that using System.err.println isn't
> the most portable or=
 elegant way to provide this information to the
> programmer executing the =
test.
>
> What I really want is a GUI that allows the programmer to select =
a
> failed test from a list of failed tests, and then to view supplemental
=
> test data I provide him/her.
>
> I was thinking I could do this by comple=
ting the following tasks:
>
> - Implementing the RunListener interface in J=
Unit.
> - Create an extension of Exception that could contain a HashMap of
=
> simple parameters and that would be passed to the constructor of a
> Fail=
ure object from within a test.
> - Creating Failure objects in my tests tha=
t contain the supplemental
> failrure data.
> - Passing these failure objec=
ts to my RunListener implementaiton.
> - Creating a FailureProcessor class =
that displays a GUI with the
> information in my RunListener implemenation =
to show the programmer
> executing my tests the supplemental failure data a=
s described above.
> (FailureProcessor would be an interface so that you co=
uld do different
> things with the supplemental failure data, not just show=
 it in a GUI.)
>
> Before I begin this work, I wanted to ask if there was a=
 better way to
> do this. I know I could use a logging framework from withi=
n my test
> method, but I really want to work within the JUnut framework, n=
ot
> outside of it. I also want a nice little GUI, not a log file.
>
> How =
are other programmers handling instances when they want to display
> supple=
mental data on failed tests? Does my approach sound reasonable?
>
> The Sun=
burned Surveyor
